...of "pet" mountain lion in a house claiming it broke into their house etc. Then someone else posted about a new deadly rattlesnake from the Mohave or something. All with easily reversible search images but people ate it up. It's such a weird phenomenon

Have any of my tweeps who are in Facebook groups revolving ag or rural areas ever notice this weird stream of misinformation regarding wildlife? Someone posted trail camera footage of wolves from Idaho claiming it was taken in shaver. Someone else posted a screenshot...
@MammalMitchell I figured just based on the greenery but that's still pretty cool to see Tule elk in other spots of the state
@gwenckatz My camera traps play this game all the time. They time travel back and forth dates
@MammalMitchell Ohhh gorgeous. Can you reveal the overal location? I wonder if our cameras crossed paths? Based on the greenery I doubt it
... but a quick and certain death is also the main reason for passing out shots. A certain shot should in my opinion be the first lesson of hunting everywhere (safety excluded of course).

...on when I learned how to hunt. It's about respecting the animal first and foremost. I know it sounds hypocritical to respect an animal you are about to kill and it's something that I think cannot be put into words. It's deeper than just not wanting an animal to suffer...

...and not be able to track it or not be able to finish the job. It sucks and it looks like its not gonna be wild turkey for thanksgiving but it definitely made me want to press on for a future opportunity. Passing on a shot is something that was instilled on to me early...

I had the opportunity to take a turkey twice over the past few days. I didn't take the shot. I knew it would come to this as I was pretty unfamiliar with bird hunting in a crossbow and also both shots had an element of uncertainty to them. I did not want to injure a bird...
@gwenckatz What is Hive?

FWIW the regulations for putting camera traps in various European countries are so so different than the USA with privacy concerns being the main issue. If you are planning on doing it read up on your local laws first. https://t.co/lrdNOMFTIN

I don't like using bait or "sure things" as a camera trapper. It deducts a lot from the experience of camera trapping (unless of course research protocols demand it) but with a very limited window in Sweden, I did opt to put a camera at this landowner's salt lick. https://t.co/WKbIOUmVia

I still have a lot to learn about moose. It doesn't help that I took this over the winter break in Sweden and California doesn't have moose.
